coursePurpose: Analyze complex economic events to identify and extract relevant information necessary to record technical accounting transactions with transparency and accuracy in accordance with U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles
Recognize estimates, judgements, and assumptions on financial statements
Critically evaluate financial reporting decisions, including recognizing the impact of accounting policies on financial statements
topicsCovered: Earnings per share calculations and reporting
learningOutcomes: Apply the BYU Marriott Values to class and classmate interactions to improve learning and the classroom experience for yourself and others
Apply financial accounting standards and concepts to various business situations
Use the FASB Accounting Standards Codification to understand and apply U.S. GAAP
Apply ethical considerations to financial reporting issues
Demonstrate effective communication skills via class discussion and ability to discuss subject matter in ad hoc discussions

requiredMaterials.title: Intermediate Accounting
requiredMaterials.format: Both digital platform and loose-leaf print version
requiredMaterials.note: Purchase both - digital not always available, deadlines not adjusted for technical issues

requiredMaterials.title: Financial Calculator
requiredMaterials.restrictions: No programmable/graphing calculators (e.g., TI-85), no smartphones, smartwatches, AI, or apps on exams

characteristicsOfSuccessfulStudents: Bring optimism and grit - hard things are doable with steady effort
Define success by inputs - set goals for preparation and practice
Prepare before class - skim/read, attempt problems, arrive with questions
Practice first, then check - do problems before looking at solutions
Ask early - use TAs and faculty office hours before you're stuck
Support each other - people learn at different speeds, help and learn together
Have fun - this is challenging and you're capable

grading.overview: Grading with flexibility for Sections 1 & 2. Students choose grading path at beginning of each section.

optionB.name: Opt-In Option
optionB.remappOpportunity: If score below 75% on multiple-choice portion of exam, can complete exam rework to raise multiple-choice score up to 75%
optionB.reworkNote: Must be completed individually, intended to help master key foundational concepts

section3.note: No final exam - replaced with cumulative project

learningReflections.frequency: Generally at end of each class
learningReflections.process: Reflect on faculty-provided question, record thoughts
learningReflections.grading: Four Canvas quizzes during semester assess participation and insights

preClassKnowledgeDemonstrations.format: Open book, open notes, strictly individual (no AI)
preClassKnowledgeDemonstrations.sections1And2: Graded in Option A, ungraded in Option B
preClassKnowledgeDemonstrations.section3: Required and graded for all students
preClassKnowledgeDemonstrations.practiceExercises: Ungraded practice exercises available before graded demonstrations
preClassKnowledgeDemonstrations.dropPolicy: Only count five highest scores per section (provides flexibility for unexpected absences, illness, personal conflicts)

postClassReviews.timing: Available few days after material covered in class
postClassReviews.purpose: Review material before students forget concepts
postClassReviews.format: Open book, open notes, can discuss but must submit own answers
postClassReviews.attempts: Four attempts with no loss of points
postClassReviews.sections1And2: Graded in Option A, ungraded but encouraged in Option B
postClassReviews.noDrops: Not eligible to be dropped - allow four attempts over 2 days

miniAssessments.description: Short, targeted assignments designed to deepen understanding of key concepts
miniAssessments.types: May include short problems, brief written responses, or applied analysis tasks
miniAssessments.purpose: Reinforce learning, provide timely feedback, prepare for final project

exams.sections1And2: One exam at end of each section
exams.coverage: Readings, classroom discussions, quizzes, other assignments
exams.reworkOption: Available for Option B if score below 75% on multiple-choice portion

cumulativeProject.description: Apply course concepts in new context, communicate analysis in thoughtful, professional way
cumulativeProject.purpose: Demonstrate technical accounting excellence while practicing professional communication

classOrganization.preClassPreparation: Canvas Pages for each class list pre-class assignments
classOrganization.ungradedExercises: Ungraded pre-class exercises and homework suggested for most classes
classOrganization.aiDiscouragement: Google or AI not good way to internalize material
classOrganization.inClassAssessments: Typically unannounced, can occur any class period

classroomAbsences.notification: Notify faculty in advance with brief explanation
classroomAbsences.healthPriority: If unwell or may be contagious, stay home
classroomAbsences.noRecording: Class sessions will not be recorded
classroomAbsences.noIndividualNotes: Faculty will not provide individualized notes for missed classes
classroomAbsences.materialsPosted: In-class materials will be posted after each session
classroomAbsences.support: Reach out to classmates, TA, or faculty for additional clarification

professionalism.standards: Emerging professionals - consistent preparation, respectful participation, thoughtful communication, emotional intelligence, contributions to positive class culture
professionalism.handling: If concerns arise, will meet to plan improvement. Ongoing unprofessional behavior will affect grade

honorCode: Students expected to be honest. Any work presented as your own must be your own work and not that of another or of AI. Violations may result in failing grade and university disciplinary action.

aiPolicy.acknowledgement: Growing influence of Generative AI in academic and business settings
aiPolicy.generalUsage: May use GenAI to support learning and enhance deliverables but not as shortcut to avoid learning
aiPolicy.restriction: Use of AI in assessments of knowledge (knowledge demonstrations, review quizzes, exams, reflections, projects) constitutes academic dishonesty

studentDisability.accommodation: Reasonable accommodations reviewed for qualified students

sexualMisconduct.contact: Title IX Coordinator at t9coordinator@byu.edu or 801-422-8692 or 1085 WSC
sexualMisconduct.advocacy: Confidential Sexual Assault Survivor Advocate available

policies.respectfulEnvironment: No demeaning comments about career or major choices. Personal agency is fundamental. No right to criticize lawful choices of another.
